bit about what the criteria for a good cve is we introduced this concept uh me
and partner David man uh from merer at the uh second workshop on vulnerability
databases at Purdue in uh January 1999 and in that at at that time we
didn't know that it was miter that was going to be doing the cve stuff we just knew something like that had to be done
so we outlined four different criteria for what a good cve would do to help you
uh uh achieve the goals that uh that that I discussed in previous slides so
first of all this is a pretty obvious one we want to be able to enumerate and discriminate between all known
vulnerabilities secondly we want to assign a standard unique name to each vulnerability so that everyone can use
that name and because we want the naming space to be out there we need the the
list itself to be open and sharable uh without any distribution
restrictions and then finally and this is one of the real challenges is we wanted to exist independently of the uh
multiple perspectives of what a vulnerability is what we keep finding over and over again is that everyone has
a different definition a different notion of what a vulnerability
is as we started developing the cve concept we had a few uh design
considerations uh that that that we brought into play one of them was to be
as simple as possible we wanted to minimize the amount of workload that that we had to do the amount of overlap
with existing vulnerability database efforts as well uh and with the editorial board we wanted to minimize
the amount of workload that they would wind up doing in addition it's important to
support the lookup of cve names and I'll talk about a couple tricks that we do to
do that later um and uh really trying to involve diverse players across the
security community and uh you saw some of that diversity in the editorial board a lot of different types of individuals
and organizations coming from a lot of different angles who are still operating
in the uh vulnerability space so let's look in at a little bit
more detail at uh Criterion one just uh list and discriminate between all known

place and while the common vulnerabilities and exposures name that it has today is kind of clunky Once Upon
a Time it used to be called common vulnerability enumeration um turns out though that
what we were trying to do with uh helping uh integrate information from

so this resulted in some terminological Warfare across different members of the
uh of the CV editorial board in terms of what was a vulnerability or what wasn't a vulnerability uh in addition should

the summer of 1999 and uh finally hit upon this concept of uh of
exposure um which now Bruce schneer is also using in a completely different way but oh well that's life um the notion of
an exposure in the cve context is a security problem or concern that doesn't
necessarily directly allow access to a system but could be used as a stepping stone so information is a good example
and our favorite uh uh Whipping Boy happens to be running finger the purpose of finger is you know to list all the

50% of all reported security problems are not acknowledged by the security

that we're asking nowadays uh after a bit of reflection and a bit of

and regardless how much verification are we really going to want to go through in

cve okay let alone whether it's real or what a vulnerability is what is a known

there's a lot of people out there a lot of organizations that go out and collect vulnerability information populate their

dumped on packet storm that's written in broken English with some exploit that may or

challenge so we get our vulnerability information to populate the CV list from various
sources and we sort of hold that internal within within miter we convert
them into these things called submissions submissions from these different data sources we then take all

that ultimately uh get a number and get propos to the editorial board for

where we have three different sources of information one of the things that we
that one of our evolving design considerations that I alluded to was we need to make it easy to look up a cve
name what that translates into partially is we need to account for the fact that
different people will use slightly different spellings of an individual
application or uh uh security vulnerability or so on so what we do is
for each raw submission we convert that into a whole whole set of keywords um we use the uh the references and whatever
descriptions and short uh names that might be in the submission we um we don't treat periods
or hyphens as word separators in this space like a lot of search engines would think about version numbers 2.4 you want

in application names or on the Unix command line within particular unix
commands what we use is the CV TOA surus to help convert each of these keyword
into one official uh official words so take for example uh buffer overflow
which some people call Buffer overrun same thing so we convert all instances
of the phrase buffer overrun into buffer overflow um one of my one of my favorite
examples here is a command called PF disp g p ay that a lot of people out
there probably think is actually called PF display Well turns out near as I can tell uh looking at the official SGI

can tell so the actual name of that program is PF disp yet a lot of people see it and immediately read it as PF
display call it PF display if you go and look for PF display on the CV website
it'll convert that into PF display valy is the official one um another uh thing about PF display
is you'll actually see that in a number of CGI scanners someone somewhere saw it his PF
display stuck it into their CGI scanner and everyone else who wrote their own CGI scanner copied that so it's kind of
interesting um w uftp three or four different ways that someone might spell it just for the same
application same thing for Internet Explorer um and we've got uh hundreds of
things like this hundreds of little tricks that we try and do to at least normalize the space of

keywords we then perform what's called uh submission matching each submission that we're dealing with we match against
the space of all other submissions the other cve uh candidates and entries other cve items themselves and we do
some basic information retrieval stuff weighted sums that basically uh
favors keywords that are more rare so um
you know wfp relatively speaking is more rare than buffer overflow is as a as a
keyword so this generally tends to Cluster things uh based on application
or in some cases version number so we'll sometimes get false positives uh on version number just because you have
vulnerabilities and completely different packages that happen to have the uh the same version
number we then um uh for for each submission the 10
closest matches based on this algorithm are generated and then a human goes and reviews them and says okay looking

for each for each submission due to the way the algorithm works when you're looking at one submission
uh let's say you're looking at submission B1 here that might show up in
the matches the top 10 matches for submission C1 as you'll as you see in the uh box on the right hand side but
the converse isn't necessarily true C1 wouldn't necessarily always show
up in the in the top 10 closest matches for
B1 we then take all of these match submissions we know that a equals B equal C and so on and then we do a
transitive closure basically we just take all of the submissions that have been matched against all others and
combine those into groups of related submissions um this helps us to
uh this gives us a number of different data points that we can then work with one submission might have one reference
another submission might have a different set of references one might describe the problem a little bit better
than another one we've got a lot of different data points there to work with and in addition there might be some very
similar vulnerabilities in very similar if not the same versions of software we at least have all of that information

all of the different referen relying on past experience in some cases or in many
cases when we get submissions there aren't any any candidates aren't any things named with cve yet so our task

better know something by you might know something better by aert advisory than
by what the cve name is we write the description uh and we apply these things called content decisions consistency

something that's in cve and that's a useful piece of information as well those submissions might have additional
references that we could use for example this is this is the biggest uh
bottleneck that we deal with in terms of even just getting to the point of assigning candidate names the early
names to these cve things that's one of the reasons why it might be a delay of
of a month or more uh before uh an initial CV candidate name comes out after initial reports we're depending on
the other data sources to feed us some of the uh challenges that we
face within this refinement one of them is really identifying duplicate issues you need to go really far down into the
weeds and sometimes the information just isn't there you might get down to the point of looking at source codes uh

problem well which of the three reported security problems did it actually fix you don't necessarily

details to be really certain whether they're talking about this vulnerability or that vulnerability uh consider the
practice of a number of vendors of crediting an individ the individual who research or who discovered a problem a
lot of those researchers names keep coming up over and over again right they might have found multiple
vulnerabilities within the course of just a month or two or a few months and once the vendor gets to the point where
they've actually patched the problem and published it you don't know which of the three vulnerabilities that the researcher has found in that product is
actually being addressed by the bulletin so one thing that we're discovering though is by working more
closely with vendors the vendors know the answer to this so we're trying to work more with the vend vendors in order
to consult them on that um there can also be delays between
the initial discovery of of a problem in the and the uh later uh security advisory as well and that that can pose
some challenges you know if you have a vendor who's very slow and responding to something they might not uh acknowledge
a vulnerability posst and advisory until six months maybe even a year after the initial vulnerability report are you
really sure that they're fixing the problem that was reported 6 month mon or a year ago or they found some other
problem that they're fixing you can't necessarily be sure that's some of the challenges that we face with respect to cve that's a challenge that anyone who's
trying to manage vulnerability information from a lot of different sources really faces we're hoping that's
that cve will help to clear that up if you have a bunch of different advisories
all of which use cve names in them then you can immediately see whether they're
really talking about the same problem or not um another another thing is that what
the researcher sees who reported the vulnerability versus what is actually going on uh under the hood based on what
the vendor knows can be completely different the researcher knows this is especially the case in closed Source the
the researcher knows I tried this attack it caused this thing to crash and therefore I conclude that the problem is
here often times you'll run into the vendors saying uh you know some Mal for
form Med input was can be provided which will cause this particular module that the that the researcher never actually
identified to cause a problem uh and we've we've observed a number of cases
where what the researcher reports and what the vendor reports are so different that we wind up creating actually two
different candidates two separate candidates and if we're doing that in cve then the vulnerability databases
that you're using are doing that too it's just a a problem with a lot of noise and lack of really good lowlevel
information uh having that available to you that can be a that can be a challenge and we we sort of have to bear

vulnerabilities or a real pain um PHP for example has certain kinds of
vulnerabilities that are fairly unique to it uh Internet Explorer security model um can be a challenge to

previous years um there's just too much information out there too so that's a
real challenge just to manage all of that uh in addition we don't have the luxury of long descriptions so we write
these fairly tur descriptions and yet we need to include enough information there to allow you to distinguish between all
the different cves and then writing and following good uh consisten
rules those consistency rules are called content decisions they're really explicit guidelines that we try and
publicize for what goes into cve and what it and what it looks like and one
of the reasons for that is so that other people can understand how we develop cve and what inherent biases so to speak
there are uh in there you know I talked about the vulnerability scanners count
uh where one had 500 vulnerabilities and another one had 300 what we're trying to do with CV is
at least document the way that we come up with whatever numbers whatever numbers we do um there are three
different types of content decisions one of them uh is called an inclusion content decisions uh what goes into CV
what doesn't uh another type of uh content decision is is abstraction there are often cases where this this comes
into play when with having people talking about different kinds of vulnerabilities or different numbers of
vulnerabilities you might look at a particular problem and say that's one vulnerability someone else might look at the exact same set of information and

to document uh which choices we actually make along the way these things are pretty difficult to
document though um there were a lot of exceptions trying to deal with missing information is a challenge so as one

incomplete information really is the challenge and I talked a little bit about

mail commands so there's even some inconsistency up here that um is really more of a

two particular candidates discuss completely different vulnerabilities so we separate those um
yet for this uh 201119 vulnerability uh there was a problem

challenges that we face with respect to dealing with vulnerabilities in open source as well as closed Source because

when we're trying to deal with vulnerabilities that appear in uh multiple executables as part of the same software package uh consider uh this uh
these two scripts uh PHP scripts called mlog and uh myog um they both appeared
in the same package they had basically the same one vulnerable line of code could have been a a cut and paste error

sometimes two candidates get produced sometimes one gets produced
um there are other examples for example how do you deal with uh passwords is

item that says the stupid CIS admin didn't disable the default password on

thing in cve or we have hundreds if not thousands um configuration problems also
